content.text: The need for an accurate X-Cache header - a reliable header that correctly indicates whether a request counted against customer rate limit quota. Infrastructure team acknowledged that the current header is unreliable, and this visibility is essential for us to properly manage rate limit consumption.

fields.summary: Accurate X-Cache Header:

content.text: A response header/flag that indicates when stale-while-revalidate or stale-when-rate-limited strategies have returned stale content.
Part of Advanced Caching,

fields.summary: Stale Content Flag

content.text: When using the content model sharing feature between spaces:
Some customers would like the ability to create a new entry for a shared content model directly from within the UI of the consuming space.
Currently, they can link to existing entries from a consuming space; they cannot create a new entry of the shared content type. Editors must switch to the source space to create these entries.

fields.summary: Allow creation of new entries for shared content models from the consuming space

content.text: Customer is looking for contextual bandits

To add customer insights, open an idea and navigate to the Insights tab. The following mandatory information should be added as an Insight to the idea to enable Salesforce roll-ups and PM merging and consolidation.
How does the customer describe the problem/need?
Explain the root of the issue, what is the customer trying to achieve beyond the request for a new/improved feature.
How urgent is the problem/need for the customer?
Can either be Anecdotal / Nice-to-have / Blocker
Customer salesforce profile
Add the salesforce URL in the box “attach a link”. This step is critical for the salesforce integration to work.
Other useful links
Please link to relevant chorus calls or other background information for Product Management

fields.summary: Contextual bandits

content.text: Client: OUA - 6KHUKJk65ej1v8PpHcJdfD
Summary:
Client wishes to to
surface / display GraphQL query complexity per content model

so teams can spot and fix hot spots before hitting limits. Specifically, they’re asking for a built-in complexity estimate that breaks down which fields drive the cost (e.g., Rich Text embeds and references with high/undefined limits) on each model’s detail page, plus an at-a-glance
Complexity
indicator/column on the models list to quickly identify risky models.
Client message:

We recently noticed that our GraphQL query complexity had really blown out and was reaching the limit. We did a full investigation and found that a couple of models didn't have proper limits set and their maximum complexity was very large. We considered creating a custom app to calculate this maximum complexity for us, to be visible on each model, but then thought it might be something you could build into Contentful, as it seems like it would be a pretty handy feature.
Maybe it could be a new section on the model page, to outline where the complexity is coming from:
And / or a column on the model listings page:

fields.summary: Display the maximum complexity limits label on content models

content.text: Customers interested in Contentful Personalization are increasingly using Angular, a framework that our personalization tool does not currently support.

fields.summary: Angular support for Contentful Personalization

content.text: FYI
Version history does not currently display status-only changes, such as when an entry is unpublished or republished without content edits.
This makes it hard to identify when downtime is caused by accidental unpublishing.

fields.summary: Status Changes Visible in Version History

content.text: Would like to select a icon to represent a custom component from a default list. While provided a custom URL is helpful it would be great if there was just a standard list to pick from. Then use the URL when something truly custom is needed.

fields.summary: Provide a default icon list to select custom component icons from

content.text: Have a CDA request that shows how close you are to hitting the rate limit

fields.summary: Copy of Have a CDA request that shows how close you are to hitting the rate limit

content.text: Customer is requesting more granular personalization metric tracking across devices, platforms, and domains.

They face challenges tracking users across devices and platforms (web, mobile app, logged in vs logged out experience) which prevents them from measuring complete conversion funnels natively in Contentful.
Metrics intended for high-level KPIs are repurposed for lower-level click tracking, leading to system mismatches.
Lack of cross-domain/session user identification resulting in fragmentary conversion tracking.
Privacy and architectural concerns prevent implementation of personalization and tracking within logged-in web apps or mobile apps.
Manual solutions include backend stitching of user data and events using UTM tagging and internal logging, which is time consuming and cumbersome.

fields.summary: Personalization Tracking Across Devices, Platforms, Domains

content.text: This feature would allow users to configure the Slack app to send notifications to users via direct message.

fields.summary: Send Slack app notifications directly to users

content.text: FYI,
, this signal is related to workflows.
While many customers use Teams to manage environment access, permissions don’t currently work as expected with environment aliases.
Current state:
Contentful supports environment aliases, allowing spaces to point a static alias (like "qa") to any environment, facilitating seamless switching for testing and deployment.
Roles and permissions—including environment access—are managed in the role editor. You can grant access to "selected environments" or "manage and use all environments."
When assigned via Teams, environment-level permission is respected, but combining multiple roles may lead to unexpected access results if not configured precisely.
Known Issues:

There is ambiguity and challenge when permissions are set for Teams on environment aliases. If a user role specifies access by alias, the mapped environment must also be selected for the user's role, or issues can arise where no access is granted.
The documentation recommends explicitly defining allowed environments, and clarifies that alias IDs (like "qa") can be used for API access,
but in practice, some permission assignments do not correctly propagate through the alias mapping—a known shortcoming.

For now, space admins can regularly review and test the actual permissions granted, ensuring that both alias and underlying environments are selected where needed. For complex workflows, assigning multiple roles to users and careful testing of access is necessary

fields.summary: Environment access control via teams and aliases

content.text: FYI
regarding Inspire Brands
Contentfuls db layer has a few core scalability problems related to Search and database performance:

We are often seeing database queries related to Full Text Search triggering Pages or High CPU alerts, see e.g. (TODO). This impacts the overall query performance for all customers and creates a lot of support burden on the engineers, on-call etc.
Related to this, we see very poor search experience for big spaces and enterprise customers, atm many of them basically can not use Full Text Search, e.g. Mercedes. (See e.g.
all the red boxes
in this query performance overview)

In general, Full Text Search today lacks a variety of features that were originally planned but could not be added because we had to implement it in the Content Databases where we would compete too much with other resources. For some context see e.g.
this overview

With the Content Pipeline we are now in a position to enable solutions for all of these pain points. In contrast to where Team Content Storage had to constrain themselves two years ago on their FTS iteration, we can now actually pipe all the data from the content databases to a third party offering like OpenSearch.
AC (or longer term goal)
FTS is moved out of the Content Databases and provided exclusively from a different secondary data store optimized for this query pattern.

fields.summary: Improve query and db performance by moving fts out of content databases

content.text: As a Content Author, I would like the ability to control which references are deep cloned versus left as a reference to the existing entry. Ideally, this can be configured per content type. For example, when cloning a page, I wouldn’t want global elements like navigation or footers to be duplicated.

fields.summary: Deep Clone App Improvement - Control which references are deep-cloned

content.text: When experiments/personalizations are running and they have not reached statistical significance yet, the customer is looking for us to give a prediction on what timeframe (based on traffic volume) it is forecasted to reach a statistical significance.
Applies to both personalizations and experimentations.

fields.summary: Forecasted timeframe to reach a statistical significance

content.text: Customer needs to be able to decide what locale code from their org is their default, currently it is hardcoded to en-us.

content.text: The customer would like version history in non-master environments.

fields.summary: Version history in non-master environments

content.text: Reassigned to
from

, I don’t own this product area. However, we will unlikely support versioning in non-master spaces because only the master space is designed for production use. SLAs only apply to the master environment. This appears to be an ask to work around our pricing models: They likely want to run production projects in non-master environments.
Agree with this assessment below. Even if we could support it, i think marketers and editors should work on master only (with preview as the safe space to iterate and test ideas).
fyi since we recently chatted about this

Customers have mentioned that when they are in the process of translating or localizing content, there's no way for them to quickly understand what percent of the fields on each locale has actually been translated yet and which ones are remaining. It's tough to determine if the content is actually close to being ready to go out the door.

fields.summary: Display how complete (%s) translations are for each locale

content.text: thanks for the signal!
Do they translate manual, with the support of apps, with ai actions?
We are currently looking into translation opportunities, so i am curious to understand how they work

They currently do manual translation. They’re looking to do AI translation with human review for each translated field. The interesting part is that their translators are not full time translators; they’re in other roles at the company that happen to speak the desired language and have been tasked with this additional job of translation. Looking to accelerate this and take much of the burden off of their plate by moving them toward translation reviewers.
interesting! and are they exploring ai actions for this new initiative or are they looking into TMS tools to do this job?
They’re looking to use AI actions!

Customers have mentioned the desire to clearly see who and what has changed content, even when it’s in draft state. Especially with AI and humans both working on content, users want to see who made changes and what those changes were.

fields.summary: Show differences in content changes prior to publish

fields.summary: Bulk AI Actions (Run AI across multiple content entries)

content.text: Customer would like more granular permissions for CMA tokens would be really useful for service accounts. Being able to limit space, environment and possibly event scope operations, would allow us to avoid situation where single token has too broad access.

fields.summary: Granular permissions for CMA Tokens.

content.text: The customer is requesting enhanced permission controls that allow for clear separation between two development teams working within the same space.
Specifically, they would like the ability to:
Assign separate roles or permissions to each team.
Restrict or isolate access to specific content models, API keys, and other configuration elements.
Allow both teams to have full access to the resources required for their respective site functionalities, without interfering with each other’s configurations.
This feature would enable better access management, security, and collaboration when multiple development teams are working within a shared environment.

fields.summary: Granular Permissions for Multiple Development Teams Within a Single Space

content.text: This sounds more like a use case for having separate spaces. Is this a workaround they’re trying to do to avoid paying for an extra space?
potentially, they more think of it as a new use case when dealing with smaller site but I agree it a workaround.
If we assume they are operating in a single space, then this is a governance/permissioning issue not a content modeling issue, going to reassign to you.
Customer would like to have a default text field added as part of the asset content type, for mandatory text input.

fields.summary: Default text field for Asset Content Type

content.text: When dealing with custom roles/permissions, admins and owners can’t impersonate the roles they have created to check functionality and access. Allowing admins to impersonate the custom roles they have created would help to troubleshoot issues that editors have, especially for less experienced content creators.

fields.summary: Give owners/admins ability to impersonate other roles to troubleshoot problems

content.text: Currently our audit logs are formatted as an array of JSON objects on a single line.
Example: [{ "id": 50, "name": "John" }, { "id": 51, "name": "Jane" }]
The problem is that Athena cannot query multiple records effectively from S3 when formatted this way.
BP is requesting a proposed format with one JSON object per line to support Athena queries:
{ "id": 50, "name": "John" }
{ "id": 51, "name": "Jane" }

fields.summary: Audit Log: change the audit logs file format to newline-delimited JSON

content.text: Hi
, you can directly paste the Salesforce account URL into the link field. This helps us to auto-fetch the account revenue.
Putting this on hold for now, because we don’t have any plans on doing this. It is for me the first time I hear about this. But we will keep a listening to customers and adjust as we learn more.

When errors occur in the rich text editor, Contentful highlights that the field has an error ie. only bold text allowed, but doesn’t show where the error is like in a Word doc. In long pieces of content, this slows down the editorial / review process.

content.text: Users are able to change the name of the “Content Type” folder in Views. If they do so, new content types no longer appear in the list.
This is easy to fix (just change the name back, and then make a small change in the new content type, then revert that change); however, there is no warning when a user changes the name.
Suggestions:
Include information about this in our documentation
Add a warning when customers click “Rename” on this folder OR
Prohibit customers from renaming the folder

fields.summary: Warn users that changing the name of the "Content Type" view folder stops it from auto-populating with the new content types

content.text: Can you share a screenshot or try to reproduce the issue and share here please?
Sure!
In this recording, I have changed the name of the view to “Content Type
s

”, and there is no warning about how this will prevent newly created types from appearing in the list. I create a new content type (“Testttt”), but it does not appear in the list. Once I have changed it back to “Content Type”, it works as expected (I create a new content type, “Second Test”, and it automatically appears in the list).
Per my Slack conversation in #prd-creators-isotopes
, this is expected behavior because the folder needs to be named “Content Type” for the auto-update to work. The customer who reported this to me had no way of knowing this, though.
